/-- If `x + y` is irrational, then at least one of `x` and `y` is irrational. -/
theorem âˆ€ {x y : â„}, Irrational (x + y) â†’ Irrational x âˆ¨ Irrational y :=

/-- There is an irrational number `r` between any two reals `x < r < y`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {x y : â„}, x < y â†’ âˆƒ r, Irrational r âˆ§ x < r âˆ§ r < y :=

/-- To show a reflexive relation `r : Î± â†’ Î± â†’ Prop` holds over `x y : Î±`,
it suffices to show it holds when `x â‰  y`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î± : Type u_1} {r : Î± â†’ Î± â†’ Prop}, Reflexive r â†’ âˆ€ {x y : Î±}, (x â‰  y â†’ r x y) â†’ r x y :=

/-- The product `r * x`, `r : â„š`, `r â‰  0`, is a Liouville number with exponent `p` if and only if
`x` satisfies the same condition. -/
theorem âˆ€ {p x : â„} {r : â„š}, r â‰  0 â†’ (LiouvilleWith p (â†‘r * x) â†” LiouvilleWith p x) :=

/-- The product `x * r`, `r : â„š`, `r â‰  0`, is a Liouville number with exponent `p` if and only if
`x` satisfies the same condition. -/
theorem âˆ€ {p x : â„} {r : â„š}, r â‰  0 â†’ (LiouvilleWith p (x * â†‘r) â†” LiouvilleWith p x) :=

/-- A transcendental real number is irrational. -/
theorem âˆ€ {r : â„}, Transcendental â„š r â†’ Irrational r :=

/-- If `x^n`, `n > 0`, is integer and is not the `n`-th power of an integer, then
`x` is irrational. -/
theorem âˆ€ {x : â„} (n : â„•) (m : â„¤), x ^ n = â†‘m â†’ (Â¬âˆƒ y, x = â†‘y) â†’ 0 < n â†’ Irrational x :=

/-- If `x^n = m` is an integer and `n` does not divide the `multiplicity p m`, then `x`
is irrational. -/
theorem âˆ€ {x : â„} (n : â„•) {m : â„¤} (hm : m â‰  0) (p : â„•) [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)],
  x ^ n = â†‘m â†’ Part.get (multiplicity (â†‘p) m) (_ : multiplicity.Finite (â†‘p) m) % n â‰  0 â†’ Irrational x :=

/-- The product of a Liouville number and a nonzero rational number is again a Liouville number. -/
theorem âˆ€ {p x : â„} {r : â„š}, LiouvilleWith p x â†’ r â‰  0 â†’ LiouvilleWith p (x * â†‘r) :=

/-- If `â€–râ€– < 1`, then `âˆ‘' n : â„•, n * r ^ n = r / (1 - r) ^ 2`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {ğ•œ : Type u_1} [inst : NormedField ğ•œ] [inst_1 : CompleteSpace ğ•œ] {r : ğ•œ},
  â€–râ€– < 1 â†’ âˆ‘' (n : â„•), â†‘n * r ^ n = r / (1 - r) ^ 2 :=

/-- If $r$ is rational $(r \neq 0)$ and $x$ is irrational, prove that $r+x$ is irrational. -/
theorem

/-- If a set is bounded below and above, and nonempty, its infimum is less than or equal to
its supremum. -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î± : Type u_1} [inst : ConditionallyCompleteLattice Î±] {s : Set Î±},
  BddBelow s â†’ BddAbove s â†’ Set.Nonempty s â†’ sInf s â‰¤ sSup s :=

/-- Any lower bound is less than the set infimum. -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î± : Type u_1} [self : CompleteSemilatticeInf Î±] (s : Set Î±) (a : Î±), (âˆ€ (b : Î±), b âˆˆ s â†’ a â‰¤ b) â†’ a â‰¤ sInf s :=

/-- Auxiliary lemma to show that the infimum of seminorms is well-defined. -/
theorem âˆ€ {ğ•œ : Type u_2} {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedField ğ•œ] [inst_1 : AddCommGroup E] [inst_2 : Module ğ•œ E]
  {p q : Seminorm ğ•œ E} {x : E}, BddBelow (Set.range fun u => â†‘p u + â†‘q (x - u)) :=

/-- The infimum of an intersection of two sets is bounded below by the maximum of the
infima of each set, if all sets are bounded below and nonempty. -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î± : Type u_1} [inst : ConditionallyCompleteLattice Î±] {s t : Set Î±},
  BddBelow s â†’ BddBelow t â†’ Set.Nonempty (s âˆ© t) â†’ sInf s âŠ” sInf t â‰¤ sInf (s âˆ© t) :=

/-- $\lim_{x\to-\infty}|x|=+\infty$ -/

/-- A least element of a set is the infimum of this set. -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î± : Type u_1} [inst : ConditionallyCompleteLattice Î±] {s : Set Î±} {a : Î±}, IsLeast s a â†’ sInf s = a :=

/-- Any element of a set is less than the set supremum. -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î± : Type u_1} [self : CompleteSemilatticeSup Î±] (s : Set Î±) (a : Î±), a âˆˆ s â†’ a â‰¤ sSup s :=

/-- If `A âŠ‚ B`, then `A` is less than `B` in the colex order. Note the converse does not hold, as
`âŠ†` is not a linear order. -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î± : Type u_1} [inst : LinearOrder Î±] {A B : Finset Î±}, A âŠ‚ B â†’ Finset.toColex A < Finset.toColex B :=

/-- `a â‰¤ -b â†’ b â‰¤ -a` on ereal -/
theorem âˆ€ {a b : EReal}, a â‰¤ -b â†’ b â‰¤ -a :=

/-- The image under an antitone function of a set which is bounded below is bounded above. -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î± : Type u} {Î² : Type v} [inst : Preorder Î±] [inst_1 : Preorder Î²] {f : Î± â†’ Î²} {s t : Set Î±},

/-- Let $A$ be a nonempty set of real numbers which is bounded below. Let $-A$ be the set of all numbers $-x$, where $x \in A$. Prove that $\inf A=-\sup (-A)$. -/
theorem

/-- We can assume that a minimal solution to `a ^ 4 + b ^ 4 = c ^ 2` has
`a` odd and `c` positive. -/
theorem âˆ€ {a b c : â„¤}, Fermat42 a b c â†’ âˆƒ a0 b0 c0, Fermat42.Minimal a0 b0 c0 âˆ§ a0 % 2 = 1 âˆ§ 0 < c0 :=

/-- We can assume that a minimal solution to `a ^ 4 + b ^ 4 = c ^ 2` has positive `c`. -/

theorem âˆ€ {a b c : â„¤}, Fermat42 a b c â†’ âˆƒ a0 b0 c0, Fermat42.Minimal a0 b0 c0 âˆ§ a0 % 2 = 1 :=

/-- a minimal solution to `a ^ 4 + b ^ 4 = c ^ 2` must have `a` and `b` coprime. -/

theorem âˆ€ {a b c : â„¤}, Fermat42 a b c â†’ âˆƒ a0 b0 c0, Fermat42.Minimal a0 b0 c0 :=

theorem âˆ€ {Î± : Type u_1} [self : CanonicallyOrderedMonoid Î±] {a b : Î±}, a â‰¤ b â†’ âˆƒ c, b = a * c :=

/-- The product of a countable family of separable spaces is a separable space. -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î¹ : Type u_1} {X : Î¹ â†’ Type u_2} [inst : (i : Î¹) â†’ TopologicalSpace (X i)]
  [inst_1 : âˆ€ (i : Î¹), TopologicalSpace.SeparableSpace (X i)] [inst_2 : Countable Î¹],
  TopologicalSpace.SeparableSpace ((i : Î¹) â†’ X i) :=

/-- A compact set in an emetric space is separable, i.e., it is the closure of a countable set. -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î³ : Type w} [inst : EMetricSpace Î³] {s : Set Î³}, IsCompact s â†’ âˆƒ t, t âŠ† s âˆ§ Set.Countable t âˆ§ s = closure t :=

/-- A compact set in a pseudo emetric space is separable, i.e., it is a subset of the closure of a
countable set. -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î± : Type u} [inst : PseudoEMetricSpace Î±] {s : Set Î±}, IsCompact s â†’ âˆƒ t, t âŠ† s âˆ§ Set.Countable t âˆ§ s âŠ† closure t :=

/-- A topological space with discrete topology is separable iff it is countable. -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î± : Type u} [t : TopologicalSpace Î±] [inst : DiscreteTopology Î±], TopologicalSpace.SeparableSpace Î± â†” Countable Î± :=

/-- Points of a finite set can be separated by open sets from each other. -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î± : Type u} [inst : TopologicalSpace Î±] [inst_1 : T2Space Î±] {s : Set Î±},
  Set.Finite s â†’ âˆƒ U, (âˆ€ (x : Î±), x âˆˆ U x âˆ§ IsOpen (U x)) âˆ§ Set.PairwiseDisjoint s U :=

/-- A uniform space with countably generated `ğ“¤ X` is pseudo metrizable. -/
theorem âˆ€ {X : Type u_1} [inst : UniformSpace X] [inst_1 : Filter.IsCountablyGenerated (uniformity X)],
  TopologicalSpace.PseudoMetrizableSpace X :=

/-- Every separable metric space embeds isometrically in `â„“^âˆ(â„•)`. -/
theorem âˆ€ (Î± : Type u) [inst : MetricSpace Î±] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace.SeparableSpace Î±], âˆƒ f, Isometry f :=

/-- The product of two separable spaces is a separable space. -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î± : Type u} [t : TopologicalSpace Î±] {Î² : Type u_1} [inst : TopologicalSpace Î²]
  [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace.SeparableSpace Î±] [inst_2 : TopologicalSpace.SeparableSpace Î²],
  TopologicalSpace.SeparableSpace (Î± Ã— Î²) :=

/-- In a separable space, a family of nonempty disjoint open sets is countable. -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î± : Type u} [t : TopologicalSpace Î±] [inst : TopologicalSpace.SeparableSpace Î±] {Î¹ : Type u_1} {s : Î¹ â†’ Set Î±}
  {a : Set Î¹},
  Set.PairwiseDisjoint a s â†’
    (âˆ€ (i : Î¹), i âˆˆ a â†’ IsOpen (s i)) â†’ (âˆ€ (i : Î¹), i âˆˆ a â†’ Set.Nonempty (s i)) â†’ Set.Countable a :=

theorem âˆ€ {Î± : Type u} {Î² : Type v} [inst : PseudoMetricSpace Î±] {f : Î² â†’ Î±} [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace Î²],
  Inducing f â†’ âˆ€ {s : Set Î±}, TopologicalSpace.IsSeparable s â†’ TopologicalSpace.IsSeparable (f â»Â¹' s) :=

theorem

such that the distance between `g âˆ˜ e` and `f` is at most `(2 / 3) * â€–fâ€–`. -/

/-- Let `X` be a metric space. Let `K : Î¹ â†’ Set X` be a locally finite family of closed sets, let

/-- A complex differentiable function `f : â„‚ â†’ E` is continuously differentiable at every point. -/
theorem âˆ€ {E : Type u} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace â„‚ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {f : â„‚ â†’ E},
  Differentiable â„‚ f â†’ âˆ€ {n : â„•âˆ}, ContDiff â„‚ n f :=

/-- If `f : â„‚ â†’ E` is complex differentiable on some open set `s`, then it is continuously
differentiable on `s`. -/

  {f : â„‚ â†’ E}, DifferentiableOn â„‚ f s â†’ IsOpen s â†’ ContDiffOn â„‚ n f s :=

/-- If `f : â„‚ â†’ E` is continuous on a closed ball of positive radius and is differentiable at all
but countably many points of the corresponding open ball, then it is analytic on the open ball with
coefficients of the power series given by Cauchy integral formulas. -/
theorem âˆ€ {E : Type u} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace â„‚ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {R : NNReal} {c : â„‚}
  {f : â„‚ â†’ E} {s : Set â„‚},
  Set.Countable s â†’
    ContinuousOn f (Metric.closedBall c â†‘R) â†’
      (âˆ€ (z : â„‚), z âˆˆ Metric.ball c â†‘R \ s â†’ DifferentiableAt â„‚ f z) â†’
        0 < R â†’ HasFPowerSeriesOnBall f (cauchyPowerSeries f c â†‘R) c â†‘R :=

/-- A useful form of the **closed graph theorem** : let `f` be a linear map between two Banach
spaces. To show that `f` is continuous, it suffices to show that for any convergent sequence

/-- A continuous function is bounded below on a compact set. -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î± : Type u_1} {Î² : Type u_2} [inst : LinearOrder Î±] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace Î±] [inst_2 : OrderClosedTopology Î±]
  [inst_3 : TopologicalSpace Î²] [inst_4 : Nonempty Î±] {f : Î² â†’ Î±} {K : Set Î²},
  IsCompact K â†’ ContinuousOn f K â†’ BddBelow (f '' K) :=

/-- A continuous function on a closed interval with `f a = f b` takes either its maximum
or its minimum value at a point in the interior of the interval. -/
theorem âˆ€ (f : â„ â†’ â„) {a b : â„},
  a < b â†’ ContinuousOn f (Set.Icc a b) â†’ f a = f b â†’ âˆƒ c, c âˆˆ Set.Ioo a b âˆ§ IsExtrOn f (Set.Icc a b) c :=

/-- A continuous function on a closed interval with `f a = f b` has a local extremum at some
point of the corresponding open interval. -/
theorem âˆ€ (f : â„ â†’ â„) {a b : â„}, a < b â†’ ContinuousOn f (Set.Icc a b) â†’ f a = f b â†’ âˆƒ c, c âˆˆ Set.Ioo a b âˆ§ IsLocalExtr f c :=

/-- A continuous function is bounded above on a compact set. -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î± : Type u_1} {Î² : Type u_2} [inst : LinearOrder Î±] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace Î±] [inst_2 : OrderClosedTopology Î±]
  [inst_3 : TopologicalSpace Î²] [inst_4 : Nonempty Î±] {f : Î² â†’ Î±} {K : Set Î²},
  IsCompact K â†’ ContinuousOn f K â†’ BddAbove (f '' K) :=

/-- If `f : â„‚ â†’ E` is continuous the closed annulus `r â‰¤ â€–z - câ€– â‰¤ R`, `0 < r â‰¤ R`, and is complex
differentiable at all but countably many points of its interior, then the integrals of
`f z / (z - c)` (formally, `(z - c)â»Â¹ â€¢ f z`) over the circles `â€–z - câ€– = r` and `â€–z - câ€– = R` are
equal to each other. -/
theorem âˆ€ {E : Type u} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace â„‚ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {c : â„‚} {r R : â„},
  0 < r â†’
    r â‰¤ R â†’
      âˆ€ {f : â„‚ â†’ E} {s : Set â„‚},
        Set.Countable s â†’
          ContinuousOn f (Metric.closedBall c R \ Metric.ball c r) â†’
            (âˆ€ (z : â„‚), z âˆˆ (Metric.ball c R \ Metric.closedBall c r) \ s â†’ DifferentiableAt â„‚ f z) â†’
              (âˆ® (z : â„‚) in C(c, R), (z - c)â»Â¹ â€¢ f z) = âˆ® (z : â„‚) in C(c, r), (z - c)â»Â¹ â€¢ f z :=

/-- **Intermediate Value Theorem** for continuous functions on closed intervals, unordered case. -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î± : Type u} [inst : ConditionallyCompleteLinearOrder Î±] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace Î±] [inst_2 : OrderTopology Î±]
  [inst_3 : DenselyOrdered Î±] {Î´ : Type u_1} [inst_4 : LinearOrder Î´] [inst_5 : TopologicalSpace Î´]
  [inst_6 : OrderClosedTopology Î´] {a b : Î±} {f : Î± â†’ Î´},
  ContinuousOn f (Set.uIcc a b) â†’ Set.uIcc (f a) (f b) âŠ† f '' Set.uIcc a b :=

/-- If `f` is a monotone function on a neighborhood of `a` and the image of this neighborhood under
`f` meets every interval `(b, f a)`, `b < f a`, and every interval `(f a, b)`, `b > f a`, then `f`
is continuous at `a`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î± : Type u_1} {Î² : Type u_2} [inst : LinearOrder Î±] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace Î±] [inst_2 : OrderTopology Î±]
  [inst_3 : LinearOrder Î²] [inst_4 : TopologicalSpace Î²] [inst_5 : OrderTopology Î²] {f : Î± â†’ Î²} {s : Set Î±} {a : Î±},
  MonotoneOn f s â†’
    s âˆˆ nhds a â†’
      (âˆ€ (b : Î²), b < f a â†’ âˆƒ c, c âˆˆ s âˆ§ f c âˆˆ Set.Ioo b (f a)) â†’
        (âˆ€ (b : Î²), b > f a â†’ âˆƒ c, c âˆˆ s âˆ§ f c âˆˆ Set.Ioo (f a) b) â†’ ContinuousAt f a :=

/-- If `f` and `g` are continuous on `[a, b]`, `a < b`, `f x â‰¤ g x` on this interval, and
`f c < g c` at some point `c âˆˆ [a, b]`, then `âˆ« x in a..b, f x < âˆ« x in a..b, g x`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {f g : â„ â†’ â„} {a b : â„},
  a < b â†’
    ContinuousOn f (Set.Icc a b) â†’
      ContinuousOn g (Set.Icc a b) â†’
        (âˆ€ (x : â„), x âˆˆ Set.Ioc a b â†’ f x â‰¤ g x) â†’
          (âˆƒ c, c âˆˆ Set.Icc a b âˆ§ f c < g c) â†’ âˆ« (x : â„) in a..b, f x < âˆ« (x : â„) in a..b, g x :=

/-- If `f : â„ â†’ â„` is integrable on `(a, b]` for real numbers `a < b`, and positive on the interior
of the interval, then its integral over `a..b` is strictly positive. -/
theorem âˆ€ {f : â„ â†’ â„} {a b : â„},
  IntervalIntegrable f MeasureTheory.volume a b â†’
    (âˆ€ (x : â„), x âˆˆ Set.Ioo a b â†’ 0 < f x) â†’ a < b â†’ 0 < âˆ« (x : â„) in a..b, f x :=

/-- Intermediate value theorem for two functions: if `f` and `g` are two continuous functions
on a preconnected space and `f a â‰¤ g a` and `g b â‰¤ f b`, then for some `x` we have `f x = g x`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {X : Type u} {Î± : Type v} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_1 : LinearOrder Î±] [inst_2 : TopologicalSpace Î±]
  [inst_3 : OrderClosedTopology Î±] [inst_4 : PreconnectedSpace X] {a b : X} {f g : X â†’ Î±},
  Continuous f â†’ Continuous g â†’ f a â‰¤ g a â†’ g b â‰¤ f b â†’ âˆƒ x, f x = g x :=

/-- Suppose $f$ is a real function with domain $R^{1}$ which has the intermediate value property: if $f(a)<c<f(b)$, then $f(x)=c$ for some $x$ between $a$ and $b$. Suppose also, for every rational $r$, that the set of all $x$ with $f(x)=r$ is closed. Prove that $f$ is continuous. -/
theorem

/-- Let `f` be a function continuous on a convex (or, equivalently, connected) subset `D`
of the real line. If `f` is differentiable on the interior of `D` and `f'` is nonnegative, then

/-- If a function `f` is continuous and `f'` is strictly monotone on `â„` then `f` is strictly

/-- Let `f` be a function continuous on a convex (or, equivalently, connected) subset `D`

  Convex â„ D â†’
    âˆ€ {f : â„ â†’ â„},

/-- Intermediate value theorem for two functions: if `f` and `g` are two continuous functions
on a preconnected space and `f a â‰¤ g a` and `g b â‰¤ f b`, then for some `x` we have `f x = g x`. -/

/-- Suppose (a) $f$ is continuous for $x \geq 0$, (b) $f^{\prime}(x)$ exists for $x>0$, (c) $f(0)=0$, (d) $f^{\prime}$ is monotonically increasing. Put $g(x)=\frac{f(x)}{x} \quad(x>0)$ and prove that $g$ is monotonically increasing. -/

/-- Let `X` be a topological space, and suppose that for all distinct `x,y âˆˆ X`, there
is some clopen set `U` such that `x âˆˆ U` and `y âˆ‰ U`. Then `X` is totally disconnected. -/

  (Pairwise fun x y => âˆƒ U, IsClopen U âˆ§ x âˆˆ U âˆ§ Â¬y âˆˆ U) â†’ IsTotallyDisconnected Set.univ :=

/-- In a locally compact space, for every containment `K âŠ† U` of a compact set `K` in an open
set `U`, there is a compact neighborhood `L` such that `K âŠ† L âŠ† U`: equivalently, there is a
compact `L` such that `K âŠ† interior L` and `L âŠ† U`. -/

  IsCompact K â†’ IsOpen U â†’ K âŠ† U â†’ âˆƒ L, IsCompact L âˆ§ K âŠ† interior L âˆ§ L âŠ† U :=

/-- Let `s, t âŠ† X` be two subsets of a topological space `X`.  If `t âŠ† s` and the topology induced
by `X`on `s` is discrete, then also the topology induces on `t` is discrete. -/
theorem âˆ€ {X : Type u_1} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] {s t : Set X}, DiscreteTopology â†‘s â†’ t âŠ† s â†’ DiscreteTopology â†‘t :=

/-- Given an open finite set `S` in a Tâ‚€ space, there is some `x âˆˆ S` such that `{x}` is open. -/

  Set.Finite s â†’ Set.Nonempty s â†’ IsOpen s â†’ âˆƒ x, x âˆˆ s âˆ§ IsOpen {x} :=

/-- If `U` is a neighborhood of each point of a set `s` then it is a neighborhood of `s`:
it contains an open set containing `s`. -/

/-- If a family of sets `s` generates the topology, then intersections of finite
subcollections of `s` form a topological basis. -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î± : Type u} [t : TopologicalSpace Î±] {s : Set (Set Î±)},
  t = TopologicalSpace.generateFrom s â†’
    TopologicalSpace.IsTopologicalBasis ((fun f => â‹‚â‚€ f) '' {f | Set.Finite f âˆ§ f âŠ† s}) :=

/-- The image of a topological basis under an open quotient map is a topological basis. -/
theorem âˆ€ {X : Type u_1} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] {Y : Type u_2} [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace Y] {Ï€ : X â†’ Y} {V : Set (Set X)},
  TopologicalSpace.IsTopologicalBasis V â†’
    QuotientMap Ï€ â†’ IsOpenMap Ï€ â†’ TopologicalSpace.IsTopologicalBasis (Set.image Ï€ '' V) :=

/-- In a disjoint union space `Î£ i, E i`, one can form a topological basis by taking the union of
topological bases on each of the parts of the space. -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î¹ : Type u_2} {E : Î¹ â†’ Type u_1} [inst : (i : Î¹) â†’ TopologicalSpace (E i)] {s : (i : Î¹) â†’ Set (Set (E i))},
  (âˆ€ (i : Î¹), TopologicalSpace.IsTopologicalBasis (s i)) â†’
    TopologicalSpace.IsTopologicalBasis (â‹ƒ (i : Î¹), (fun u => Sigma.mk i '' u) '' s i) :=

/-- In a sum space `Î± âŠ• Î²`, one can form a topological basis by taking the union of
topological bases on each of the two components. -/

  TopologicalSpace.IsTopologicalBasis s â†’
    âˆ€ {t : Set (Set Î²)},

        TopologicalSpace.IsTopologicalBasis ((fun u => Sum.inl '' u) '' s âˆª (fun u => Sum.inr '' u) '' t) :=

/-- The image of a topological basis "downstairs" in an open quotient is a topological basis. -/
theorem âˆ€ {X : Type u_1} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] {S : Setoid X} {V : Set (Set X)},
  TopologicalSpace.IsTopologicalBasis V â†’
    IsOpenMap Quotient.mk' â†’ TopologicalSpace.IsTopologicalBasis (Set.image Quotient.mk' '' V) :=

/-- To show that a compact set intersects the intersection of a family of closed sets,
it is sufficient to show that it intersects every finite subfamily. -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î± : Type u} [inst : TopologicalSpace Î±] {s : Set Î±} {Î¹ : Type v},

  (âˆ€ (s : Set Î±), s âˆˆ S â†’ IsOpen s) â†’ Set.Countable S â†’ (âˆ€ (s : Set Î±), s âˆˆ S â†’ Dense s) â†’ Dense (â‹‚â‚€ S) :=

/-- If a family of open sets `s` is such that every open neighbourhood contains some
member of `s`, then `s` is a topological basis. -/

  (âˆ€ (u : Set Î±), u âˆˆ s â†’ IsOpen u) â†’
    (âˆ€ (a : Î±) (u : Set Î±), a âˆˆ u â†’ IsOpen u â†’ âˆƒ v, v âˆˆ s âˆ§ a âˆˆ v âˆ§ v âŠ† u) â†’ TopologicalSpace.IsTopologicalBasis s :=

/-- If `s` is a closed set and two functions `f` and `g` are continuous on `s`,
then the set `{x âˆˆ s | f x â‰¤ g x}` is a closed set. -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î± : Type u} {Î² : Type v} [inst : TopologicalSpace Î±] [inst_1 : Preorder Î±] [t : OrderClosedTopology Î±]
  [inst_2 : TopologicalSpace Î²] {f g : Î² â†’ Î±} {s : Set Î²},
  IsClosed s â†’ ContinuousOn f s â†’ ContinuousOn g s â†’ IsClosed {x | x âˆˆ s âˆ§ f x â‰¤ g x} :=

/-- A continuous function is bounded below on a compact set. -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î± : Type u_1} {Î² : Type u_2} [inst : LinearOrder Î±] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace Î±] [inst_2 : OrderClosedTopology Î±]
  [inst_3 : TopologicalSpace Î²] [inst_4 : Nonempty Î±] {f : Î² â†’ Î±} {K : Set Î²},
  IsCompact K â†’ ContinuousOn f K â†’ BddBelow (f '' K) :=

/-- A useful form of the **closed graph theorem** : let `f` be a linear map between two Banach
spaces. To show that `f` is continuous, it suffices to show that for any convergent sequence
`uâ‚™ âŸ¶ x`, if `f(uâ‚™) âŸ¶ y` then `y = f(x)`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {ğ•œ : Type u_3} [inst : NontriviallyNormedField ğ•œ] {E : Type u_1} [inst_1 : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  [inst_2 : NormedSpace ğ•œ E] {F : Type u_2} [inst_3 : NormedAddCommGroup F] [inst_4 : NormedSpace ğ•œ F]
  [inst_5 : CompleteSpace F] [inst_6 : CompleteSpace E] (g : E â†’â‚—[ğ•œ] F),
  (âˆ€ (u : â„• â†’ E) (x : E) (y : F),
      Filter.Tendsto u Filter.atTop (nhds x) â†’ Filter.Tendsto (â†‘g âˆ˜ u) Filter.atTop (nhds y) â†’ y = â†‘g x) â†’
    Continuous â†‘g :=

/-- If `f` and `g` are continuous on `[a, b]`, `a < b`, `f x â‰¤ g x` on this interval, and
`f c < g c` at some point `c âˆˆ [a, b]`, then `âˆ« x in a..b, f x < âˆ« x in a..b, g x`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {f g : â„ â†’ â„} {a b : â„},
  a < b â†’
    ContinuousOn f (Set.Icc a b) â†’
      ContinuousOn g (Set.Icc a b) â†’
        (âˆ€ (x : â„), x âˆˆ Set.Ioc a b â†’ f x â‰¤ g x) â†’
          (âˆƒ c, c âˆˆ Set.Icc a b âˆ§ f c < g c) â†’ âˆ« (x : â„) in a..b, f x < âˆ« (x : â„) in a..b, g x :=

/-- Intermediate value theorem for two functions: if `f` and `g` are two continuous functions
on a preconnected space and `f a â‰¤ g a` and `g b â‰¤ f b`, then for some `x` we have `f x = g x`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {X : Type u} {Î± : Type v} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_1 : LinearOrder Î±] [inst_2 : TopologicalSpace Î±]
  [inst_3 : OrderClosedTopology Î±] [inst_4 : PreconnectedSpace X] {a b : X} {f g : X â†’ Î±},
  Continuous f â†’ Continuous g â†’ f a â‰¤ g a â†’ g b â‰¤ f b â†’ âˆƒ x, f x = g x :=

/-- A continuous function is bounded above on a compact set. -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î± : Type u_1} {Î² : Type u_2} [inst : LinearOrder Î±] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace Î±] [inst_2 : OrderClosedTopology Î±]
  [inst_3 : TopologicalSpace Î²] [inst_4 : Nonempty Î±] {f : Î² â†’ Î±} {K : Set Î²},
  IsCompact K â†’ ContinuousOn f K â†’ BddAbove (f '' K) :=

/-- A HÃ¶lder continuous function is uniformly continuous -/
theorem âˆ€ {X : Type u_1} {Y : Type u_2} [inst : PseudoEMetricSpace X] [inst_1 : PseudoEMetricSpace Y] {C r : NNReal} {f : X â†’ Y}
  {s : Set X}, HolderOnWith C r f s â†’ 0 < r â†’ UniformContinuousOn f s :=

/-- Intermediate value theorem for two functions: if `f` and `g` are two functions continuous
on a preconnected set `s` and for some `a b âˆˆ s` we have `f a â‰¤ g a` and `g b â‰¤ f b`,
then for some `x âˆˆ s` we have `f x = g x`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {X : Type u} {Î± : Type v} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_1 : LinearOrder Î±] [inst_2 : TopologicalSpace Î±]
  [inst_3 : OrderClosedTopology Î±] {s : Set X},
  IsPreconnected s â†’
    âˆ€ {a b : X},
      a âˆˆ s â†’
        b âˆˆ s â†’ âˆ€ {f g : X â†’ Î±}, ContinuousOn f s â†’ ContinuousOn g s â†’ f a â‰¤ g a â†’ g b â‰¤ f b â†’ âˆƒ x, x âˆˆ s âˆ§ f x = g x :=

/-- For any `x : â„` the sequence $\frac{f^n(x)-x}{n}$ tends to the translation number of `f`.
In particular, this limit does not depend on `x`. -/
theorem âˆ€ (f : CircleDeg1Lift) (x : â„),
  Filter.Tendsto (fun n => (â†‘(f ^ n) x - x) / â†‘n) Filter.atTop (nhds (CircleDeg1Lift.translationNumber f)) :=

/-- Consider a series of functions `âˆ‘' n, f n x`. If the series converges at a
point, and all functions in the series are differentiable with a summable bound on the derivatives,
then the series converges everywhere. -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î± : Type u_1} {ğ•œ : Type u_2} {E : Type u_3} {F : Type u_4} [inst : IsROrC ğ•œ] [inst_1 : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  [inst_2 : NormedSpace ğ•œ E] [inst_3 : NormedAddCommGroup F] [inst_4 : CompleteSpace F] {u : Î± â†’ â„}
  [inst_5 : NormedSpace ğ•œ F] {f : Î± â†’ E â†’ F} {f' : Î± â†’ E â†’ E â†’L[ğ•œ] F} {xâ‚€ : E},
  Summable u â†’
    (âˆ€ (n : Î±) (x : E), HasFDerivAt (f n) (f' n x) x) â†’
      (âˆ€ (n : Î±) (x : E), â€–f' n xâ€– â‰¤ u n) â†’ (Summable fun n => f n xâ‚€) â†’ âˆ€ (x : E), Summable fun n => f n x :=

/-- Shows that
$\sum_{k = 0}^{n - 1} (e^{X})^k = \sum_{p = 0}^{\infty} \sum_{k = 0}^{n - 1} \frac{k^p}{p!}X^p$. -/
theorem âˆ€ {A : Type u_1} [inst : CommRing A] [inst_1 : Algebra â„š A] (n : â„•),
  (Finset.sum (Finset.range n) fun k => PowerSeries.exp A ^ k) =
    PowerSeries.mk fun p => Finset.sum (Finset.range n) fun k => â†‘(k ^ p) * â†‘(algebraMap â„š A) (â†‘(Nat.factorial p))â»Â¹ :=

/-- If $x â‰¤ f x$ for all $x$ (we write this as `id â‰¤ f`), then the same is true for any iterate
`f^[n]` of `f`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î± : Type u_1} [inst : Preorder Î±] {f : Î± â†’ Î±}, id â‰¤ f â†’ âˆ€ (n : â„•), id â‰¤ f^[n] :=

/-- If the sequence with `n`-th term the the sup norm of `Î» x, f (x + n)` on the interval `Icc 0 1`,
for `n âˆˆ â„¤`, is summable, then `f` is integrable on `â„`. -/

  (Summable fun n => â€–ContinuousMap.restrict (Set.Icc 0 1) (ContinuousMap.comp f (ContinuousMap.addRight â†‘n))â€–) â†’
    MeasureTheory.Integrable â†‘f :=

/-- If `f` is a monotone map and `x â‰¤ f x` at some point `x`, then the iterates `f^[n] x` form
a monotone sequence. -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î± : Type u_1} [inst : Preorder Î±] {f : Î± â†’ Î±} {x : Î±}, Monotone f â†’ x â‰¤ f x â†’ Monotone fun n => f^[n] x :=

/-- If `f : â„• â†’ Î±` has sum `a`, then the partial sums `âˆ‘_{i=0}^{n-1} f i` converge to `a`. -/

  HasSum f a â†’ Filter.Tendsto (fun n => Finset.sum (Finset.range n) fun i => f i) Filter.atTop (nhds a) :=

/-- The Bernstein approximations
```

```
for a continuous function `f : C([0,1], â„)` converge uniformly to `f` as `n` tends to infinity.

This is the proof given in [Richard Beals' *Analysis, an introduction*][beals-analysis], Â§7D,

/-- Consider a series of functions `âˆ‘' n, f n x`. If the series converges at a

        (Summable fun n => f n xâ‚€) â†’ âˆ€ (x : E), HasFDerivAt (fun y => âˆ‘' (n : Î±), f n y) (âˆ‘' (n : Î±), f' n x) x :=

/-- If a function f has a derivative f' at x, a rescaled version of f around x converges to f',
i.e., `n (f (x + (1/n) v) - f x)` converges to `f' v`. More generally, if `c n` tends to infinity

  [inst_2 : NormedSpace ğ•œ E] {F : Type u_3} [inst_3 : NormedAddCommGroup F] [inst_4 : NormedSpace ğ•œ F] {f : E â†’ F}
  {f' : E â†’L[ğ•œ] F} {x : E} {s : Set E},
  HasFDerivWithinAt f f' s x â†’
    âˆ€ {Î± : Type u_4} (l : Filter Î±) {c : Î± â†’ ğ•œ} {d : Î± â†’ E} {v : E},
      (âˆ€á¶  (n : Î±) in l, x + d n âˆˆ s) â†’
        Filter.Tendsto (fun n => â€–c nâ€–) l Filter.atTop â†’

            Filter.Tendsto (fun n => c n â€¢ (f (x + d n) - f x)) l (nhds (â†‘f' v)) :=

docString: Let $X$ be a topological space and let $Y$ be a metric space. Let $f_{n}: X \rightarrow Y$ be a sequence of continuous functions. Let $x_{n}$ be a sequence of points of $X$ converging to $x$. Show that if the sequence $\left(f_{n}\right)$ converges uniformly to $f$, then $\left(f_{n}\left(x_{n}\right)\right)$ converges to $f(x)$.

/-- A useful form of the **closed graph theorem** : let `f` be a linear map between two Banach

        Filter.Tendsto (fun n => F n (g n)) p (nhds (f x)) :=

compact. -/

/-- In a locally compact space every point has a compact neighborhood. -/

/-- In a locally compact space,
every neighbourhood of every point contains a compact neighbourhood of that same point. -/

  n âˆˆ nhds x â†’ âˆƒ s, s âˆˆ nhds x âˆ§ s âŠ† n âˆ§ IsCompact s :=

/-- In a locally compact space, for every containment `K âŠ† U` of a compact set `K` in an open
set `U`, there is a compact neighborhood `L` such that `K âŠ† L âŠ† U`: equivalently, there is a
compact `L` such that `K âŠ† interior L` and `L âŠ† U`. -/

  IsCompact K â†’ IsOpen U â†’ K âŠ† U â†’ âˆƒ L, IsCompact L âˆ§ K âŠ† interior L âˆ§ L âŠ† U :=

/-- If `n % 4 = 1`, then `(-1)^(n/2) = 1`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {n : â„•}, n % 4 = 1 â†’ (-1) ^ (n / 2) = 1 :=

/-- If `n % 4 = 3`, then `(-1)^(n/2) = -1`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {n : â„•}, n % 4 = 3 â†’ (-1) ^ (n / 2) = -1 :=

/-- If a prime `p` divides `n` such that `-1` is a square modulo `n`, then `p % 4 â‰  3`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {p n : â„•}, Nat.Prime p â†’ p âˆ£ n â†’ IsSquare (-1) â†’ p % 4 â‰  3 :=

/-- For `n â‰  1`, `(n-1)!` is congruent to `-1` modulo `n` only if n is prime. -/
theorem âˆ€ {n : â„•}, â†‘(Nat.factorial (n - 1)) = -1 â†’ n â‰  1 â†’ Nat.Prime n :=

/-- If `a` is even, then `n` is odd iff `n % a` is odd. -/
theorem âˆ€ {n a : â„•}, Even a â†’ (Odd (n % a) â†” Odd n) :=

/-- `-2` is a square modulo an odd prime `p` iff `p` is congruent to `1` or `3` mod `8`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {p : â„•} [inst : Fact (Nat.Prime p)], p â‰  2 â†’ (IsSquare (-2) â†” p % 8 = 1 âˆ¨ p % 8 = 3) :=

/-- If `n` is odd and `a` is even, then `n % a` is odd. -/
theorem âˆ€ {n a : â„•}, Odd n â†’ Even a â†’ Odd (n % a) :=

/-- If `-1` is a square modulo the natural number `n`, then `n` is a sum of two squares. -/
theorem âˆ€ {n : â„•}, IsSquare (-1) â†’ âˆƒ x y, n = x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 :=

/-- The value of `Ï‡â‚ˆ n`, for `n : â„¤`, depends only on `n % 8`. -/
theorem âˆ€ (n : â„¤), â†‘ZMod.Ï‡â‚ˆ â†‘n = â†‘ZMod.Ï‡â‚ˆ â†‘(n % 8) :=

/-- If the natural number `n` is a sum of two squares of coprime natural numbers, then
`-1` is a square modulo `n`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {n x y : â„•}, n = x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 â†’ Nat.coprime x y â†’ IsSquare (-1) :=

/-- For all odd $n$ show that $8 \mid n^{2}-1$. -/
theorem

theorem âˆ€ (n : â„•), (âˆ‘' (i : â„•), if n â‰¤ i then 2â»Â¹ ^ i else 0) = 2 * 2â»Â¹ ^ n :=

/-- `2` is a square modulo an odd prime `p` iff `p` is congruent to `1` or `7` mod `8`. -/

/-- If `Irreducible (cyclotomic (2 ^ k) K)` (in particular for `K = â„š`) and `k` is at least `2`,
then the norm of `zeta (2 ^ k) K L - 1` is `2`. -/

then so does the first. -/

/-- The proof that `a` is a solution to the Pell equation `x^2 - d*y^2 = 1` -/
theorem âˆ€ {d : â„¤} (a : Pell.Solutionâ‚ d), Pell.Solutionâ‚.x a ^ 2 - d * Pell.Solutionâ‚.y a ^ 2 = 1 :=

/-- In a finite field of characteristic `2`, all elements are squares. -/

$\sum_{k = 0}^{n - 1} (e^{X})^k = \sum_{p = 0}^{\infty} \sum_{k = 0}^{n - 1} \frac{k^p}{p!}X^p$. -/
theorem âˆ€ {A : Type u_1} [inst : CommRing A] [inst_1 : Algebra â„š A] (n : â„•),
  (Finset.sum (Finset.range n) fun k => PowerSeries.exp A ^ k) =
    PowerSeries.mk fun p => Finset.sum (Finset.range n) fun k => â†‘(k ^ p) * â†‘(algebraMap â„š A) (â†‘(Nat.factorial p))â»Â¹ :=

/-- A prime power divides `n!` iff it is at most the sum of the quotients `n / p ^ i`.
This sum is expressed over the set `Ico 1 b` where `b` is any bound greater than `log p n` -/

/-- For any `n`, we have `log_stirlingSeq 1 - log_stirlingSeq n â‰¤ 1/4 * âˆ‘' 1/k^2` -/

/-- For any `p`, the power of `p` in `n^k` is `k` times the power in `n` -/

/-- **Legendre's Theorem**

The `p`-adic valuation of `n!` is the sum of the quotients `n / p ^ i`. This sum is expressed
over the finset `Ico 1 b` where `b` is any bound greater than `log p n`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {p n b : â„•} [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)],
  Nat.log p n < b â†’ padicValNat p (Nat.factorial n) = Finset.sum (Finset.Ico 1 b) fun i => n / p ^ i :=

/-- Infinitely many natural numbers are equal to `d` mod `n`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {n : â„•}, n â‰  0 â†’ âˆ€ (d : â„•), âˆƒá¶  (m : â„•) in Filter.atTop, m â‰¡ d [MOD n] :=

/-- For `d âˆ£ n`, the totient of `n/d` equals the number of values `k < n` such that `gcd n k = d` -/
theorem âˆ€ {n d : â„•}, d âˆ£ n â†’ Nat.totient (n / d) = Finset.card (Finset.filter (fun k => Nat.gcd n k = d) (Finset.range n)) :=

/-- **Legendre's Theorem**

The multiplicity of a prime in `n!` is the sum of the quotients `n / p ^ i`. This sum is expressed
over the finset `Ico 1 b` where `b` is any bound greater than `log p n`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {p : â„•},
  Nat.Prime p â†’
    âˆ€ {n b : â„•}, Nat.log p n < b â†’ multiplicity p (Nat.factorial n) = â†‘(Finset.sum (Finset.Ico 1 b) fun i => n / p ^ i) :=

/-- Gauss' lemma. The Legendre symbol can be computed by considering the number of naturals less
than `p/2` such that `(a * x) % p > p / 2`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {p : â„•} [inst : Fact (Nat.Prime p)] {a : â„¤},
  p â‰  2 â†’

      legendreSym p a =
        (-1) ^ Finset.card (Finset.filter (fun x => p / 2 < ZMod.val (â†‘a * â†‘x)) (Finset.Ico 1 (Nat.succ (p / 2)))) :=

theorem âˆ€ {Î± : Type u_1} [inst : CancelCommMonoidWithZero Î±] [inst_1 : UniqueFactorizationMonoid Î±]
  [inst_2 : NormalizationMonoid Î±] [inst_3 : DecidableEq Î±] {x : Î±} {n : â„•}, factorization (x ^ n) = n â€¢ factorization x :=

/-- For any positive `k : â„•` there are infinitely many primes `p` such that `p â‰¡ 1 [MOD k]`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {k : â„•}, k â‰  0 â†’ Set.Infinite {p | Nat.Prime p âˆ§ p â‰¡ 1 [MOD k]} :=

/-- For `n â‰  1`, `(n-1)!` is congruent to `-1` modulo `n` only if n is prime. -/
theorem âˆ€ {n : â„•}, â†‘(Nat.factorial (n - 1)) = -1 â†’ n â‰  1 â†’ Nat.Prime n :=

/-- Infinitely many natural numbers are equal to `d` mod `n`. -/

/-- If two integers are congruent to a sufficiently large modulus,
they are equal. -/
theorem âˆ€ {a b c : â„¤}, a % b = c â†’ Int.natAbs (a - c) < Int.natAbs b â†’ a = c :=

/-- **Wilson's Lemma**: the product of `1`, ..., `p-1` is `-1` modulo `p`. -/
theorem âˆ€ (p : â„•) [inst : Fact (Nat.Prime p)], â†‘(Nat.factorial (p - 1)) = -1 :=

/-- **Wilson's Theorem**: For `n â‰  1`, `(n-1)!` is congruent to `-1` modulo `n` iff n is prime. -/
theorem âˆ€ {n : â„•}, n â‰  1 â†’ (Nat.Prime n â†” â†‘(Nat.factorial (n - 1)) = -1) :=

/-- Multiplicative congruence relations preserve natural powers. -/
theorem âˆ€ {M : Type u_1} [inst : Monoid M] (c : Con M) (n : â„•) {w x : M}, â†‘c w x â†’ â†‘c (w ^ n) (x ^ n) :=

/-- `-2` is a square modulo an odd prime `p` iff `p` is congruent to `1` or `3` mod `8`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {p : â„•} [inst : Fact (Nat.Prime p)], p â‰  2 â†’ (IsSquare (-2) â†” p % 8 = 1 âˆ¨ p % 8 = 3) :=

/-- For any positive `k : â„•` there exists an arbitrarily large prime `p` such that
`p â‰¡ 1 [MOD k]`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {k : â„•} (n : â„•), k â‰  0 â†’ âˆƒ p, Nat.Prime p âˆ§ n < p âˆ§ p â‰¡ 1 [MOD k] :=

idea that inequality of multisets corresponds to divisibility

theorem âˆ€ {m n : â„•+}, PNat.factorMultiset m â‰¤ PNat.factorMultiset n â†” m âˆ£ n :=

/-- **The Law of Quadratic Reciprocity**: if `p` and `q` are distinct odd primes, then
`(q / p) * (p / q) = (-1)^((p-1)(q-1)/4)`. -/

  p â‰  2 â†’ q â‰  2 â†’ p â‰  q â†’ legendreSym q â†‘p * legendreSym p â†‘q = (-1) ^ (p / 2 * (q / 2)) :=

/-- The Law of Quadratic Reciprocity: if `p` and `q` are odd primes and `p % 4 = 1`,
then `(q / p) = (p / q)`. -/

  p % 4 = 1 â†’ q â‰  2 â†’ legendreSym q â†‘p = legendreSym p â†‘q :=

/-- The Law of Quadratic Reciprocity: if `p` and `q` are odd primes, then
`(q / p) = (-1)^((p-1)(q-1)/4) * (p / q)`. -/

  p â‰  2 â†’ q â‰  2 â†’ legendreSym q â†‘p = (-1) ^ (p / 2 * (q / 2)) * legendreSym p â†‘q :=

/-- The `p`-adic norm of `q` is `1` if `q` is prime and not equal to `p`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {p q : â„•} [p_prime : Fact (Nat.Prime p)] [q_prime : Fact (Nat.Prime q)], p â‰  q â†’ padicNorm p â†‘q = 1 :=

/-- When `p` is prime, then the totient of `p ^ (n + 1)` is `p ^ n * (p - 1)` -/
theorem âˆ€ {p : â„•}, Nat.Prime p â†’ âˆ€ (n : â„•), Nat.totient (p ^ (n + 1)) = p ^ n * (p - 1) :=

/-- The Law of Quadratic Reciprocity: if `p` and `q` are primes that are both congruent

theorem âˆ€ {p n : â„•}, Nat.Prime p â†’ p âˆ£ n â†’ IsSquare (-1) â†’ p % 4 â‰  3 :=

/-- If `a^(p-1) = 1 mod p`, but `a^((p-1)/q) â‰  1 mod p` for all prime factors `q` of `p-1`, then `p`
is prime. This is true because `a` has order `p-1` in the multiplicative group mod `p`, so this
group must itself have order `p-1`, which only happens when `p` is prime. -/

/-- **Fermat's Little Theorem**: for all `a : â„¤` coprime to `p`, we have
`a ^ (p - 1) â‰¡ 1 [ZMOD p]`. -/

theorem âˆ€ {a : â„¤} {p : â„•} [inst : Fact (Nat.Prime p)], jacobiSym a p = 1 â†’ IsSquare â†‘a :=

/-- If `a^(p-1) = 1 mod p`, but `a^((p-1)/q) â‰  1 mod p` for all prime factors `q` of `p-1`, then `p`
is prime. This is true because `a` has order `p-1` in the multiplicative group mod `p`, so this
group must itself have order `p-1`, which only happens when `p` is prime. -/

/-- If `p` and `q` are odd primes and `p % 4 = 1`, then `q` is a square mod `p` iff
`p` is a square mod `q`. -/

/-- A prime `p` satisfies `p % 2 = 1` if and only if `p â‰  2`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {p : â„•} [inst : Fact (Nat.Prime p)], p % 2 = 1 â†” p â‰  2 :=

/-- **Fermat's Little Theorem**: for all `a : â„¤` coprime to `p`, we have
`a ^ (p - 1) â‰¡ 1 [ZMOD p]`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {p : â„•}, Nat.Prime p â†’ âˆ€ {n : â„¤}, IsCoprime n â†‘p â†’ n ^ (p - 1) â‰¡ 1 [ZMOD â†‘p] :=

/-- If an integer `a` and a prime `p` satisfy `gcd a p = 1`, then `a : ZMod p` is nonzero. -/
theorem âˆ€ {a : â„¤} {p : â„•}, Nat.Prime p â†’ Int.gcd a â†‘p = 1 â†’ â†‘a â‰  0 :=

/-- If an integer `a` and a prime `p` satisfy `gcd a p â‰  1`, then `a : ZMod p` is zero. -/
theorem âˆ€ {a : â„¤} {p : â„•}, Nat.Prime p â†’ Int.gcd a â†‘p â‰  1 â†’ â†‘a = 0 :=

/-- If `p` is a prime and `a` is an integer, then `a : ZMod p` is zero if and only if

theorem âˆ€ {a : â„¤} {p : â„•} [pp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)], â†‘a = 0 â†” Int.gcd a â†‘p â‰  1 :=

/-- If a function `f : M â†’ F` from a complex manifold to a complex normed space is holomorphic on a
(pre)connected compact open set, then it is a constant on this set. -/
theorem âˆ€ {E : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace â„‚ E] {F : Type u_4} [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup F]

    IsPreconnected U â†’ IsCompact U â†’ IsOpen U â†’ a âˆˆ U â†’ b âˆˆ U â†’ f a = f b :=

/-- A holomorphic function on a compact connected complex manifold is constant. -/

  [inst_8 : ChartedSpace H M] [inst_9 : SmoothManifoldWithCorners I M] [inst_10 : PreconnectedSpace M] {f : M â†’ F},
  MDifferentiable I (modelWithCornersSelf â„‚ F) f â†’ âˆ€ (a b : M), f a = f b :=

  [inst_3 : NormedSpace â„‚ F] {H : Type u_2} [inst_4 : TopologicalSpace H] {I : ModelWithCorners â„‚ E H}

  [inst_8 : ChartedSpace H M] [inst_9 : SmoothManifoldWithCorners I M] {f : M â†’ F},
  MDifferentiable I (modelWithCornersSelf â„‚ F) f â†’ IsLocallyConstant f :=

/-- The *open mapping theorem* for holomorphic functions, global version: if a function `g : E â†’ â„‚`
is analytic on a connected set `U`, then either it is constant on `U`, or it is open on `U` (in the
sense that it maps any open set contained in `U` to an open set in `â„‚`). -/
theorem âˆ€ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace â„‚ E] {U : Set E} {g : E â†’ â„‚},
  AnalyticOn â„‚ g U â†’
    IsPreconnected U â†’ (âˆƒ w, âˆ€ (z : E), z âˆˆ U â†’ g z = w) âˆ¨ âˆ€ (s : Set E), s âŠ† U â†’ IsOpen s â†’ IsOpen (g '' s) :=

/-- A holomorphic function on a compact connected complex manifold is the constant function `f â‰¡ v`,
for some value `v`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {E : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace â„‚ E] {F : Type u_4} [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup F]
  [inst_3 : NormedSpace â„‚ F] {H : Type u_3} [inst_4 : TopologicalSpace H] {I : ModelWithCorners â„‚ E H}
  [inst_5 : ModelWithCorners.Boundaryless I] {M : Type u_1} [inst_6 : TopologicalSpace M] [inst_7 : CompactSpace M]
  [inst_8 : ChartedSpace H M] [inst_9 : SmoothManifoldWithCorners I M] [inst_10 : PreconnectedSpace M] {f : M â†’ F},
  MDifferentiable I (modelWithCornersSelf â„‚ F) f â†’ âˆƒ v, f = Function.const M v :=

/-- **Liouville's theorem**: a complex differentiable bounded function `f : E â†’ F` is a constant. -/
theorem âˆ€ {E : Type u} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace â„‚ E] {F : Type v} [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup F]
  [inst_3 : NormedSpace â„‚ F] {f : E â†’ F}, Differentiable â„‚ f â†’ Metric.Bounded (Set.range f) â†’ âˆ€ (z w : E), f z = f w :=

/-- **Liouville's theorem**: a complex differentiable bounded function is a constant. -/
theorem âˆ€ {E : Type u} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace â„‚ E] {F : Type v} [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup F]

/-- The sum of a converging power series is continuous in its disk of convergence. -/
theorem âˆ€ {ğ•œ : Type u_3} {E : Type u_2} {F : Type u_1} [inst : NontriviallyNormedField ğ•œ] [inst_1 : NormedAddCommGroup E]

/-- Lebesgue dominated convergence theorem for series. -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î± : Type u_2} {G : Type u_3} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup G] [inst_1 : NormedSpace â„ G] {m : MeasurableSpace Î±}

  (âˆ€ (n : Î¹), MeasureTheory.AEStronglyMeasurable (F n) Î¼) â†’
    (âˆ€ (n : Î¹), âˆ€áµ (a : Î±) âˆ‚Î¼, â€–F n aâ€– â‰¤ bound n a) â†’
      (âˆ€áµ (a : Î±) âˆ‚Î¼, Summable fun n => bound n a) â†’
        (MeasureTheory.Integrable fun a => âˆ‘' (n : Î¹), bound n a) â†’
          (âˆ€áµ (a : Î±) âˆ‚Î¼, HasSum (fun n => F n a) (f a)) â†’ HasSum (fun n => âˆ« (a : Î±), F n a âˆ‚Î¼) (âˆ« (a : Î±), f a âˆ‚Î¼) :=

/-- Shows that
$\sum_{k = 0}^{n - 1} (e^{X})^k = \sum_{p = 0}^{\infty} \sum_{k = 0}^{n - 1} \frac{k^p}{p!}X^p$. -/
theorem âˆ€ {A : Type u_1} [inst : CommRing A] [inst_1 : Algebra â„š A] (n : â„•),
  (Finset.sum (Finset.range n) fun k => PowerSeries.exp A ^ k) =
    PowerSeries.mk fun p => Finset.sum (Finset.range n) fun k => â†‘(k ^ p) * â†‘(algebraMap â„š A) (â†‘(Nat.factorial p))â»Â¹ :=

/-- Uniform converence implies pointwise convergence. -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î± : Type u} {Î² : Type v} {Î¹ : Type x} [inst : UniformSpace Î²] {F : Î¹ â†’ Î± â†’ Î²} {f : Î± â†’ Î²} {s : Set Î±} {p : Filter Î¹},

/-- A series whose terms are bounded by the terms of a converging geometric series converges. -/
theorem âˆ€ {m : â„} {f : â„• â†’ â„•}, 1 < m â†’ (âˆ€ (i : â„•), i â‰¤ f i) â†’ Summable fun i => 1 / m ^ f i :=

theorem âˆ€ (z : â„‚), â†‘z.im = (z - â†‘(starRingEnd â„‚) z) / (2 * Complex.I) :=

/-- If two nonzero squares are negatives of each other in `ZMod p`, then `p % 4 â‰  3`. -/

/-- There are several equivalent ways to say that a number `z` is in fact a real number. -/

  List.TFAE [â†‘(starRingEnd K) z = z, âˆƒ r, â†‘r = z, â†‘(â†‘IsROrC.re z) = z, â†‘IsROrC.im z = 0] :=

theorem âˆ€ (n : â„•), riemannZeta (-2 * (â†‘n + 1)) = 0 :=

/-- Every nonzero natural number has a unique prime factorization -/
theorem Set.InjOn Nat.factorization {x | x â‰  0} :=

/-- If `n` is a nonzero natural number and `p â‰  1`, then there are natural numbers `e`
and `n'` such that `n'` is not divisible by `p` and `n = p^e * n'`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {n : â„•}, n â‰  0 â†’ âˆ€ (p : â„•), p â‰  1 â†’ âˆƒ e n', Â¬p âˆ£ n' âˆ§ n = p ^ e * n' :=

/-- The proposition that `n` is not zero. -/
theorem âˆ€ {R : Type u_1} [inst : Zero R] {n : R} [self : NeZero n], n â‰  0 :=

/-- Euclid's theorem on the **infinitude of primes**.
Here given in the form: for every `n`, there exists a prime number `p â‰¥ n`. -/
theorem âˆ€ (n : â„•), âˆƒ p, n â‰¤ p âˆ§ Nat.Prime p :=

/-- The digits in the base b+2 expansion of n are all less than b+2 -/
theorem âˆ€ {b m d : â„•}, d âˆˆ Nat.digits (b + 2) m â†’ d < b + 2 :=

/-- The digits in the base b expansion of n are all less than b, if b â‰¥ 2 -/
theorem âˆ€ {b m d : â„•}, 1 < b â†’ d âˆˆ Nat.digits b m â†’ d < b :=

/-- If a prime `p` divides `n` such that `-1` is a square modulo `n`, then `p % 4 â‰  3`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {p n : â„•}, Nat.Prime p â†’ p âˆ£ n â†’ IsSquare (-1) â†’ p % 4 â‰  3 :=

/-- `a ^ (n + 1) = a * a ^ n` -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î± : Type u_1} [self : LinearOrderedSemifield Î±] (n : â„•) (a : Î±),
  LinearOrderedSemifield.zpow (Int.ofNat (Nat.succ n)) a = a * LinearOrderedSemifield.zpow (Int.ofNat n) a :=

/-- an n-digit number in base b + 2 is less than (b + 2)^n -/
theorem âˆ€ {b : â„•} {l : List â„•}, (âˆ€ (x : â„•), x âˆˆ l â†’ x < b + 2) â†’ Nat.ofDigits (b + 2) l < (b + 2) ^ List.length l :=

/-- **Lifting the exponent lemma** for odd primes. -/
theorem âˆ€ {p : â„•},
  Nat.Prime p â†’
    Odd p â†’
      âˆ€ {x y : â„¤},
        â†‘p âˆ£ x - y â†’
          Â¬â†‘p âˆ£ x â†’ âˆ€ (n : â„•), multiplicity (â†‘p) (x ^ n - y ^ n) = multiplicity (â†‘p) (x - y) + multiplicity p n :=

/-- Prove that for each positive integer $n$, the number $10^{10^{10^n}}+10^{10^n}+10^n-1$ is not prime. -/
theorem

/-- The set of natural numbers that are sums of two squares is closed under multiplication. -/
theorem âˆ€ {a b x y u v : â„•}, a = x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 â†’ b = u ^ 2 + v ^ 2 â†’ âˆƒ r s, a * b = r ^ 2 + s ^ 2 :=

/-- If `-1` is a square modulo the natural number `n`, then `n` is a sum of two squares. -/
theorem âˆ€ {n : â„•}, IsSquare (-1) â†’ âˆƒ x y, n = x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 :=

/-- A natural number `n` is a sum of two squares if and only if `n = a^2 * b` with natural
numbers `a` and `b` such that `-1` is a square modulo `b`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {n : â„•}, (âˆƒ x y, n = x ^ 2 + y ^ 2) â†” âˆƒ a b, n = a ^ 2 * b âˆ§ IsSquare (-1) :=

/-- Euclid's theorem on the **infinitude of primes**.
Here given in the form: for every `n`, there exists a prime number `p â‰¥ n`. -/
theorem âˆ€ (n : â„•), âˆƒ p, n â‰¤ p âˆ§ Nat.Prime p :=

/-- If the natural number `n` is a sum of two squares of coprime natural numbers, then
`-1` is a square modulo `n`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {n x y : â„•}, n = x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 â†’ Nat.coprime x y â†’ IsSquare (-1) :=

/-- A (positive) natural number `n` is a sum of two squares if and only if the exponent of
every prime `q` such that `q % 4 = 3` in the prime factorization of `n` is even.
(The assumption `0 < n` is not present, since for `n = 0`, both sides are satisfied;
the right hand side holds, since `padicValNat q 0 = 0` by definition.) -/
theorem âˆ€ {n : â„•}, (âˆƒ x y, n = x ^ 2 + y ^ 2) â†” âˆ€ {q : â„•}, Nat.Prime q â†’ q % 4 = 3 â†’ Even (padicValNat q n) :=

/-- There are no perfect squares strictly between mÂ² and (m+1)Â² -/
theorem âˆ€ {n m : â„•}, m * m < n â†’ n < (m + 1) * (m + 1) â†’ Â¬âˆƒ t, t * t = n :=

/-- **Euler's four-square identity**, a version for natural numbers. -/
theorem âˆ€ (a b c d x y z w : â„•),
  Int.natAbs (â†‘a * â†‘x - â†‘b * â†‘y - â†‘c * â†‘z - â†‘d * â†‘w) ^ 2 + Int.natAbs (â†‘a * â†‘y + â†‘b * â†‘x + â†‘c * â†‘w - â†‘d * â†‘z) ^ 2 +
        Int.natAbs (â†‘a * â†‘z - â†‘b * â†‘w + â†‘c * â†‘x + â†‘d * â†‘y) ^ 2 +
      Int.natAbs (â†‘a * â†‘w + â†‘b * â†‘z - â†‘c * â†‘y + â†‘d * â†‘x) ^ 2 =
    (a ^ 2 + b ^ 2 + c ^ 2 + d ^ 2) * (x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 + z ^ 2 + w ^ 2) :=

/-- A sum of numbers is infinite iff one of them is infinite -/
theorem âˆ€ {Î¹ : Type u_2} {M : Type u_1} [inst : AddCommMonoid M] {s : Finset Î¹} {f : Î¹ â†’ WithTop M},
  (Finset.sum s fun i => f i) = âŠ¤ â†” âˆƒ i, i âˆˆ s âˆ§ f i = âŠ¤ :=

theorem âˆ€ (n : â„•), 512 â‰¤ n â†’ âˆƒ p, Nat.Prime p âˆ§ n < p âˆ§ p â‰¤ 2 * n :=

/-- If `H` is a subgroup of `G` of cardinality `p ^ n`, then the cardinality of the
normalizer of `H` is congruent mod `p ^ (n + 1)` to the cardinality of `G`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {G : Type u} [inst : Group G] [inst_1 : Fintype G] {p n : â„•} [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)] {H : Subgroup G},
  Fintype.card { x // x âˆˆ H } = p ^ n â†’
    Fintype.card { x // x âˆˆ Subgroup.normalizer H } â‰¡ Fintype.card G [MOD p ^ (n + 1)] :=

/-- If `H` is a subgroup of `G` of cardinality `p ^ n`,

  p ^ m âˆ£ Fintype.card G â†’
    âˆ€ (H : Subgroup G), Fintype.card { x // x âˆˆ H } = p ^ n â†’ n â‰¤ m â†’ âˆƒ K, Fintype.card { x // x âˆˆ K } = p ^ m âˆ§ H â‰¤ K :=

/-- If `H` is a subgroup of `G` of cardinality `p ^ n`,

if `p ^ (n + 1)` divides the cardinality of `G` -/
theorem âˆ€ {G : Type u} [inst : Group G] [inst_1 : Fintype G] {p n : â„•} [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)],
  p ^ (n + 1) âˆ£ Fintype.card G â†’
    âˆ€ {H : Subgroup G}, Fintype.card { x // x âˆˆ H } = p ^ n â†’ âˆƒ K, Fintype.card { x // x âˆˆ K } = p ^ (n + 1) âˆ§ H â‰¤ K :=

/-- If `H` is a `p`-subgroup but not a Sylow `p`-subgroup of cardinality `p ^ n`,
then `p ^ (n + 1)` divides the cardinality of the normalizer of `H`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {G : Type u} [inst : Group G] [inst_1 : Fintype G] {p n : â„•} [_hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)],
  p ^ (n + 1) âˆ£ Fintype.card G â†’
    âˆ€ {H : Subgroup G},
      Fintype.card { x // x âˆˆ H } = p ^ n â†’ p ^ (n + 1) âˆ£ Fintype.card { x // x âˆˆ Subgroup.normalizer H } :=

/-- If `H` is a `p`-subgroup of `G`, then the index of `H` inside its normalizer is congruent
mod `p` to the index of `H`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {G : Type u} [inst : Group G] [inst_1 : Fintype G] {p n : â„•} [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)] {H : Subgroup G},

      Fintype.card (G â§¸ H) [MOD p] :=

/-- A generalisation of **Sylow's first theorem**. If `p ^ n` divides
the cardinality of `G`, then there is a subgroup of cardinality `p ^ n` -/
theorem âˆ€ {G : Type u} [inst : Group G] [inst_1 : Fintype G] (p : â„•) {n : â„•} [inst_2 : Fact (Nat.Prime p)],
  p ^ n âˆ£ Fintype.card G â†’ âˆƒ K, Fintype.card { x // x âˆˆ K } = p ^ n :=

/-- finite p-groups with different p have coprime orders -/
theorem âˆ€ {G : Type u_2} [inst : Group G] {Gâ‚‚ : Type u_1} [inst_1 : Group Gâ‚‚] (pâ‚ pâ‚‚ : â„•) [hpâ‚ : Fact (Nat.Prime pâ‚)]
  [hpâ‚‚ : Fact (Nat.Prime pâ‚‚)],
  pâ‚ â‰  pâ‚‚ â†’
    âˆ€ (Hâ‚ : Subgroup G) (Hâ‚‚ : Subgroup Gâ‚‚) [inst_2 : Fintype { x // x âˆˆ Hâ‚ }] [inst_3 : Fintype { x // x âˆˆ Hâ‚‚ }],
      IsPGroup pâ‚ { x // x âˆˆ Hâ‚ } â†’
        IsPGroup pâ‚‚ { x // x âˆˆ Hâ‚‚ } â†’ Nat.coprime (Fintype.card { x // x âˆˆ Hâ‚ }) (Fintype.card { x // x âˆˆ Hâ‚‚ }) :=

/-- For every prime `p` dividing the order of a finite group `G` there exists an element of order
`p` in `G`. This is known as Cauchy's theorem. -/
theorem âˆ€ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] [inst_1 : Fintype G] (p : â„•) [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)],
  p âˆ£ Fintype.card G â†’ âˆƒ x, orderOf x = p :=

/-- A generalisation of **Sylow's first theorem**. If `p ^ n` divides
the cardinality of `G`, then there is a subgroup of cardinality `p ^ n` -/
theorem âˆ€ {G : Type u} [inst : Group G] [inst_1 : Fintype G] (p : â„•) {n : â„•} [inst_2 : Fact (Nat.Prime p)],
  p ^ n âˆ£ Fintype.card G â†’ âˆƒ K, Fintype.card { x // x âˆˆ K } = p ^ n :=

/-- For every prime `p` dividing the order of a finite additive group `G` there exists an element of
order `p` in `G`. This is the additive version of Cauchy's theorem. -/
theorem âˆ€ {G : Type u_1} [inst : AddGroup G] [inst_1 : Fintype G] (p : â„•) [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)],
  p âˆ£ Fintype.card G â†’ âˆƒ x, addOrderOf x = p :=

/-- The quotient by the center of a group of cardinality `p ^ 2` is cyclic. -/
theorem âˆ€ {p : â„•} {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] [inst_1 : Fintype G] [inst_2 : Fact (Nat.Prime p)],
  Fintype.card G = p ^ 2 â†’ IsCyclic (G â§¸ Subgroup.center G) :=

/-- The topological closure of a normal subgroup is normal. -/
theorem âˆ€ {G : Type u_1} [inst : TopologicalSpace G] [inst_1 : Group G] [inst_2 : TopologicalGroup G] (N : Subgroup G)
  [inst_3 : Subgroup.Normal N], Subgroup.Normal (Subgroup.topologicalClosure N) :=

/-- A generalization of **Sylow's first theorem**.
Every `p`-subgroup is contained in a Sylow `p`-subgroup. -/
theorem âˆ€ {p : â„•} {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] {P : Subgroup G}, IsPGroup p { x // x âˆˆ P } â†’ âˆƒ Q, P â‰¤ â†‘Q :=

    Fintype.card { x // x âˆˆ Subgroup.normalizer H } â‰¡ Fintype.card G [MOD p ^ (n + 1)] :=

/-- The cardinality of a Sylow subgroup is `p ^ n`
where `n` is the multiplicity of `p` in the group order. -/
theorem âˆ€ {G : Type u} [inst : Group G] [inst_1 : Fintype G] {p : â„•} [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)] (P : Sylow p G),
  Fintype.card { x // x âˆˆ â†‘P } = p ^ â†‘(Nat.factorization (Fintype.card G)) p :=

theorem âˆ€ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] (H : Subgroup G), NormalizerCondition G â†’ IsCoatom H â†’ Subgroup.Normal H :=

theorem âˆ€ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] [inst_1 : Fintype G] (p : â„•) [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)],

is a number field. -/

/-- Let R be an integral domain and f âˆˆ R[X]. Let s be a finite index set.
Then, a fraction of the form f / âˆ (g i) can be rewritten as q + âˆ‘ (r i) / (g i), where
deg(r i) < deg(g i), provided that the g i are monic and pairwise coprime. -/

  [inst_4 : IsFractionRing (Polynomial R) K] (f : Polynomial R) {Î¹ : Type u_1} {g : Î¹ â†’ Polynomial R} {s : Finset Î¹},
  (âˆ€ (i : Î¹), i âˆˆ s â†’ Polynomial.Monic (g i)) â†’

/-- A subgroup has index two if and only if there exists `a` such that for all `b`, exactly one
of `b * a` and `b` belong to `H`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] {H : Subgroup G}, Subgroup.index H = 2 â†” âˆƒ a, âˆ€ (b : G), Xor' (b * a âˆˆ H) (b âˆˆ H) :=

/-- Given a subgroup `H` of a decidable linearly ordered archimedean abelian group `G`, if there
exists a minimal element `a` of `H âˆ© G_{>0}` then `H` is generated by `a`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {G : Type u_1} [inst : LinearOrderedAddCommGroup G] [inst_1 : Archimedean G] {H : AddSubgroup G} {a : G},
  IsLeast {g | g âˆˆ H âˆ§ 0 < g} a â†’ H = AddSubgroup.closure {a} :=

/-- An additive subgroup has index two if and only if there exists `a` such that
for all `b`, exactly one of `b + a` and `b` belong to `H`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {G : Type u_1} [inst : AddGroup G] {H : AddSubgroup G},
  AddSubgroup.index H = 2 â†” âˆƒ a, âˆ€ (b : G), Xor' (b + a âˆˆ H) (b âˆˆ H) :=

/-- If `H` is a subgroup of `G`, then `Finite (Sylow p G)` implies `Finite (Sylow p H)`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {p : â„•} {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] (H : Subgroup G) [inst_1 : Finite (Sylow p G)],
  Finite (Sylow p { x // x âˆˆ H }) :=

/-- The torsion submonoid of an abelian group equals the torsion subgroup as a submonoid. -/
theorem âˆ€ (G : Type u_1) [inst : CommGroup G], CommMonoid.torsion G = (CommGroup.torsion G).toSubmonoid :=

/-- Elements of disjoint, normal subgroups commute. -/
theorem âˆ€ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] (Hâ‚ Hâ‚‚ : Subgroup G),
  Subgroup.Normal Hâ‚ â†’ Subgroup.Normal Hâ‚‚ â†’ Disjoint Hâ‚ Hâ‚‚ â†’ âˆ€ (x y : G), x âˆˆ Hâ‚ â†’ y âˆˆ Hâ‚‚ â†’ Commute x y :=

/-- If `a` commutes with `b`, then `b` commutes with `a`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {S : Type u_1} [inst : Mul S] {a b : S}, Commute a b â†’ Commute b a :=

/-- Product of a list of elements in a subgroup is in the subgroup. -/
theorem âˆ€ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] (K : Subgroup G) {l : List G}, (âˆ€ (x : G), x âˆˆ l â†’ x âˆˆ K) â†’ List.prod l âˆˆ K :=

/-- If `a` commutes with `b`, then `b` commutes with `a`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {S : Type u_1} [inst : Add S] {a b : S}, AddCommute a b â†’ AddCommute b a :=

/-- Elements of disjoint, normal subgroups commute. -/
theorem âˆ€ {G : Type u_1} [inst : AddGroup G] (Hâ‚ Hâ‚‚ : AddSubgroup G),
  AddSubgroup.Normal Hâ‚ â†’ AddSubgroup.Normal Hâ‚‚ â†’ Disjoint Hâ‚ Hâ‚‚ â†’ âˆ€ (x y : G), x âˆˆ Hâ‚ â†’ y âˆˆ Hâ‚‚ â†’ AddCommute x y :=

theorem

  I â‰  0 â†’ Set.Finite {v | v.asIdeal âˆ£ I} :=

/-- A ring `R` is Jacobson if and only if for every prime ideal `I`,
`I` can be written as the infimum of some collection of maximal ideals.

  Ideal.IsJacobson R â†”
    âˆ€ {I : Ideal R}, Ideal.IsPrime I â†’ âˆƒ M, (âˆ€ (J : Ideal R), J âˆˆ M â†’ Ideal.IsMaximal J âˆ¨ J = âŠ¤) âˆ§ I = sInf M :=

/-- If the quotient by an ideal is a field, then the ideal is maximal. -/

  (x : { x // x âˆˆ RingHom.range (RingHom.comp (Ideal.Quotient.mk I) Polynomial.C) }),

  p ^ n âˆ£ Fintype.card G â†’ âˆƒ K, Fintype.card { x // x âˆˆ K } = p ^ n :=

theorem âˆ€ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] (H : Subgroup G) {x y : G}, x âˆˆ H â†’ y âˆˆ H â†’ x * y âˆˆ H :=

  Nat.coprime (Fintype.card { x // x âˆˆ â†‘P }) (Subgroup.index â†‘P) :=

/-- If `H` is a subgroup of `G`, then `Finite (Sylow p G)` implies `Finite (Sylow p H)`. -/

  Finite (Sylow p { x // x âˆˆ H }) :=

/-- If `H` is a subgroup of `G` of cardinality `p ^ n`,
then `H` is contained in a subgroup of cardinality `p ^ (n + 1)`

theorem âˆ€ {G : Type u} [inst : Group G] [inst_1 : Fintype G] {p n : â„•} [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)],
  p ^ (n + 1) âˆ£ Fintype.card G â†’
    âˆ€ {H : Subgroup G}, Fintype.card { x // x âˆˆ H } = p ^ n â†’ âˆƒ K, Fintype.card { x // x âˆˆ K } = p ^ (n + 1) âˆ§ H â‰¤ K :=

/-- If `H` is a subgroup of `G` of cardinality `p ^ n`,
then `H` is contained in a subgroup of cardinality `p ^ m`
if `n â‰¤ m` and `p ^ m` divides the cardinality of `G` -/

  p ^ m âˆ£ Fintype.card G â†’

theorem âˆ€ {p : â„•} {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] (H : Subgroup G) [inst_1 : Finite (Sylow p G)],
  Finite (Sylow p { x // x âˆˆ H }) :=

/-- A generalization of **Sylow's first theorem**.
Every `p`-subgroup is contained in a Sylow `p`-subgroup. -/
theorem âˆ€ {p : â„•} {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] {P : Subgroup G}, IsPGroup p { x // x âˆˆ P } â†’ âˆƒ Q, P â‰¤ â†‘Q :=

/-- A generalisation of **Sylow's first theorem**. If `p ^ n` divides
the cardinality of `G`, then there is a subgroup of cardinality `p ^ n` -/
theorem âˆ€ {G : Type u} [inst : Group G] [inst_1 : Fintype G] (p : â„•) {n : â„•} [inst_2 : Fact (Nat.Prime p)],
  p ^ n âˆ£ Fintype.card G â†’ âˆƒ K, Fintype.card { x // x âˆˆ K } = p ^ n :=

/-- If `H` is a subgroup of `G` of cardinality `p ^ n`,
then `H` is contained in a subgroup of cardinality `p ^ (n + 1)`
if `p ^ (n + 1)` divides the cardinality of `G` -/
theorem âˆ€ {G : Type u} [inst : Group G] [inst_1 : Fintype G] {p n : â„•} [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)],
  p ^ (n + 1) âˆ£ Fintype.card G â†’
    âˆ€ {H : Subgroup G}, Fintype.card { x // x âˆˆ H } = p ^ n â†’ âˆƒ K, Fintype.card { x // x âˆˆ K } = p ^ (n + 1) âˆ§ H â‰¤ K :=

/-- Sylow subgroups are Hall subgroups. -/
theorem âˆ€ {G : Type u} [inst : Group G] [inst_1 : Fintype G] {p : â„•} [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)] (P : Sylow p G),
  Nat.coprime (Fintype.card { x // x âˆˆ â†‘P }) (Subgroup.index â†‘P) :=

/-- A generalisation of **Sylow's first theorem**. If `p ^ n` divides
the cardinality of `G`, then there is a subgroup of cardinality `p ^ n` -/
theorem âˆ€ {G : Type u} [inst : Group G] [inst_1 : Fintype G] (p : â„•) {n : â„•} [inst_2 : Fact (Nat.Prime p)],
  p ^ n âˆ£ Fintype.card G â†’ âˆƒ K, Fintype.card { x // x âˆˆ K } = p ^ n :=

/-- If `H` is a subgroup of `G`, then `Finite (Sylow p G)` implies `Finite (Sylow p H)`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {p : â„•} {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] (H : Subgroup G) [inst_1 : Finite (Sylow p G)],
  Finite (Sylow p { x // x âˆˆ H }) :=

/-- A generalization of **Sylow's third theorem**.
If the number of Sylow `p`-subgroups is finite, then it is congruent to `1` modulo `p`. -/
theorem âˆ€ (p : â„•) (G : Type u_1) [inst : Group G] [inst_1 : Fact (Nat.Prime p)] [inst_2 : Fintype (Sylow p G)],
  Fintype.card (Sylow p G) â‰¡ 1 [MOD p] :=

/-- A generalization of **Sylow's first theorem**.
Every `p`-subgroup is contained in a Sylow `p`-subgroup. -/
theorem âˆ€ {p : â„•} {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] {P : Subgroup G}, IsPGroup p { x // x âˆˆ P } â†’ âˆƒ Q, P â‰¤ â†‘Q :=

/-- The cardinality of a Sylow subgroup is `p ^ n`
where `n` is the multiplicity of `p` in the group order. -/
theorem âˆ€ {G : Type u} [inst : Group G] [inst_1 : Fintype G] {p : â„•} [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)] (P : Sylow p G),
  Fintype.card { x // x âˆˆ â†‘P } = p ^ â†‘(Nat.factorization (Fintype.card G)) p :=

/-- A generalization of **Sylow's second theorem**.
If the number of Sylow `p`-subgroups is finite, then all Sylow `p`-subgroups are conjugate. -/
theorem âˆ€ {p : â„•} {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)] [inst_1 : Finite (Sylow p G)],
  MulAction.IsPretransitive G (Sylow p G) :=

/-- If `H` is a subgroup of `G` of cardinality `p ^ n`, then the cardinality of the
normalizer of `H` is congruent mod `p ^ (n + 1)` to the cardinality of `G`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {G : Type u} [inst : Group G] [inst_1 : Fintype G] {p n : â„•} [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)] {H : Subgroup G},
  Fintype.card { x // x âˆˆ H } = p ^ n â†’
    Fintype.card { x // x âˆˆ Subgroup.normalizer H } â‰¡ Fintype.card G [MOD p ^ (n + 1)] :=

/-- If `H` is a `p`-subgroup but not a Sylow `p`-subgroup of cardinality `p ^ n`,
then `p ^ (n + 1)` divides the cardinality of the normalizer of `H`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {G : Type u} [inst : Group G] [inst_1 : Fintype G] {p n : â„•} [_hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)],
  p ^ (n + 1) âˆ£ Fintype.card G â†’
    âˆ€ {H : Subgroup G},
      Fintype.card { x // x âˆˆ H } = p ^ n â†’ p ^ (n + 1) âˆ£ Fintype.card { x // x âˆˆ Subgroup.normalizer H } :=

/-- If `H` is a subgroup of `G` of cardinality `p ^ n`,
then `H` is contained in a subgroup of cardinality `p ^ (n + 1)`
if `p ^ (n + 1)` divides the cardinality of `G` -/
theorem âˆ€ {G : Type u} [inst : Group G] [inst_1 : Fintype G] {p n : â„•} [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)],
  p ^ (n + 1) âˆ£ Fintype.card G â†’
    âˆ€ {H : Subgroup G}, Fintype.card { x // x âˆˆ H } = p ^ n â†’ âˆƒ K, Fintype.card { x // x âˆˆ K } = p ^ (n + 1) âˆ§ H â‰¤ K :=

/-- For every prime `p` dividing the order of a finite group `G` there exists an element of order
`p` in `G`. This is known as Cauchy's theorem. -/
theorem âˆ€ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] [inst_1 : Fintype G] (p : â„•) [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)],
  p âˆ£ Fintype.card G â†’ âˆƒ x, orderOf x = p :=

/-- The center of a group acts commutatively on that group. -/
theorem âˆ€ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G], SMulCommClass G { x // x âˆˆ Subgroup.center G } G :=

/-- The set of fixed points of the conjugation action of `G` on itself is the center of `G`. -/

/-- `N` is closed under additive conjugation -/
theorem âˆ€ {A : Type u_1} [inst : AddGroup A] {H : AddSubgroup A},
  AddSubgroup.Normal H â†’ âˆ€ (n : A), n âˆˆ H â†’ âˆ€ (g : A), g + n + -g âˆˆ H :=

/-- **Burnside's lemma** : given a finite additive group `G` acting on a set `X`,
the average number of elements fixed by each `g âˆˆ G` is the number of orbits. -/
theorem âˆ€ (Î± : Type u) (Î² : Type v) [inst : AddGroup Î±] [inst_1 : AddAction Î± Î²] [inst_2 : Fintype Î±]
  [inst_3 : (a : Î±) â†’ Fintype â†‘(AddAction.fixedBy Î± Î² a)] [inst_4 : Fintype (Quotient (AddAction.orbitRel Î± Î²))],
  (Finset.sum Finset.univ fun a => Fintype.card â†‘(AddAction.fixedBy Î± Î² a)) =
    Fintype.card (Quotient (AddAction.orbitRel Î± Î²)) * Fintype.card Î± :=

/-- The nilpotency class of a non-trivial group is one more than its quotient by the center -/

theorem âˆ€ (R : Type u_1) [inst : Ring R] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace R] [t : NonarchimedeanRing R], NonarchimedeanAddGroup R :=

/-- Let R be an integral domain and f âˆˆ R[X]. Let s be a finite index set.
Then, a fraction of the form f / âˆ (g i) can be rewritten as q + âˆ‘ (r i) / (g i), where
deg(r i) < deg(g i), provided that the g i are monic and pairwise coprime. -/
theorem âˆ€ (R : Type) [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : IsDomain R] (K : Type) [inst_2 : Field K] [inst_3 : Algebra (Polynomial R) K]
  [inst_4 : IsFractionRing (Polynomial R) K] (f : Polynomial R) {Î¹ : Type u_1} {g : Î¹ â†’ Polynomial R} {s : Finset Î¹},

/-- If `f` is a non constant polynomial with coefficients in `R`, and `P` is a prime ideal in `R`,

/-- A prime `p` satisfies `p % 2 = 1` if and only if `p â‰  2`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {p : â„•} [inst : Fact (Nat.Prime p)], p % 2 = 1 â†” p â‰  2 :=

/-- `2` is a square modulo an odd prime `p` iff `p` is congruent to `1` or `7` mod `8`. -/

/-- `-2` is a square modulo an odd prime `p` iff `p` is congruent to `1` or `3` mod `8`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {p : â„•} [inst : Fact (Nat.Prime p)], p â‰  2 â†’ (IsSquare (-2) â†” p % 8 = 1 âˆ¨ p % 8 = 3) :=

/-- The Law of Quadratic Reciprocity: if `p` and `q` are odd primes, then
`(q / p) = (-1)^((p-1)(q-1)/4) * (p / q)`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {p q : â„•} [inst : Fact (Nat.Prime p)] [inst_1 : Fact (Nat.Prime q)],
  p â‰  2 â†’ q â‰  2 â†’ legendreSym q â†‘p = (-1) ^ (p / 2 * (q / 2)) * legendreSym p â†‘q :=

/-- If `Irreducible (cyclotomic p K)` (in particular for `K = â„š`) and `p` is an odd prime,
then the norm of `Î¶ - 1` is `p`. -/

  [hpri : Fact (Nat.Prime â†‘p)] [hcyc : IsCyclotomicExtension {p} K L],

/-- **The Law of Quadratic Reciprocity**: if `p` and `q` are distinct odd primes, then
`(q / p) * (p / q) = (-1)^((p-1)(q-1)/4)`. -/
theorem âˆ€ {p q : â„•} [inst : Fact (Nat.Prime p)] [inst_1 : Fact (Nat.Prime q)],
  p â‰  2 â†’ q â‰  2 â†’ p â‰  q â†’ legendreSym q â†‘p * legendreSym p â†‘q = (-1) ^ (p / 2 * (q / 2)) :=

/-- **Lifting the exponent lemma** for `p = 2` -/
theorem âˆ€ {x y : â„¤} {n : â„•},
  2 âˆ£ x - y â†’
    Â¬2 âˆ£ x â†’
      Even n â†’ multiplicity 2 (x ^ n - y ^ n) + 1 = multiplicity 2 (x + y) + multiplicity 2 (x - y) + multiplicity 2 â†‘n :=

  [inst_3 : IsDomain A] [inst_4 : IsDomain B], IsIntegral A x â†’ Irreducible (minpoly A x) :=

prime, then the norm of `Î¶ - 1` is `p`. -/

      Irreducible (Polynomial.cyclotomic (â†‘(p ^ (k + 1))) K) â†’ p â‰  2 â†’ â†‘(Algebra.norm K) (Î¶ - 1) = â†‘â†‘p :=

theorem âˆ€ {p : â„•+} {K : Type u} (L : Type v) [inst : Field K] [inst_1 : Field L] [inst_2 : Algebra K L]
